name: Crude oil, off-shore import, at extraction
description: This cradle-to-gate unit process is for 1 kg of crude oil from foreign, off-shore sources. Crude oil extraction inputs include energy from natural gas, petroleum and other fossil fuels in addition to electricity use. The energy inputs are assumed to be the same for the domestic and imported on-shore and off-shore extraction processes.  The energy inputs of this process are taken from GREET model 2017. The emission data for the process is adapted from inventory data compiled by the National Energy Technology Lab.
category: 21: Mining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas Extraction/2111: Oil and Gas Extraction

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This unit process is representative of data collected for crude oil extraction from 2006-2013.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This process is representative of U.S. imported, off-shore crude oil extraction.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Oil is produced by drilling into porous rock structures generally located several thousand feet underground. Once an oil deposit is located, numerous holes are drilled and lined with steel casing. Some oil is brought to the surface by natural pressure in the rock structure, although most oil requires energy to drive pumps that lift oil to the surface. Once oil is on the surface, it is separated from water and stored in tanks before being transported to a refinery. In some cases, it is immediately transferred to a pipeline that transports the oil to a larger terminal.
processDocumentation.inventoryMethodDescription: Attributional; cradle to gate process. Compatible with TRACI.
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: Secondary data adapted from from GREET and NETL.
processDocumentation.completenessDescription:
TREATMENT OF MISSING ENVIRONMENTAL DATA: Elementary flows are cut-off at less than 1% based on environmental relevance.
TREATMENT OF MISSING TECHNOSPHERE DATA: Miscellaneous materials and additives, capital equipment, facilities and infrastructure, space conditioning, and support personnel requirements are not included in this system process. No gaps have been identified in this dataset.
MASS BALANCE: The mass balance was calculated by a straight comparison of inputs and outputs
processDocumentation.dataSelectionDescription: Crude oil extraction data adapted from NETL and GREET datasets.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Emission data for this process is adapted from inventory data compiled by the National Energy Technology Lab. The inventory for crude oil extraction accounts for emissions to air as reported in the NEI for U.S. extraction sites, greenhouse gas emissions from Cooney et. al. 2017, and emissions to water from EPA’s Discharge Monitoring Reports. Non-greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions inventories for foreign oil extraction are unavailable so were assumed to scale linearly according to changes in carbon dioxide emission from domestic extraction. Emissions data from each U.S. county were allocated between oil extraction and natural gas based on North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) and source classification codes included in the NEI. For cases in which not enough detail was provided from emissions records, emissions were allocated between oil and gas in that county based on the energy content of reported production. 

Solid wastes include drilling wastes and associated wastes as calculated from statistics in EPA 2000 and API 2000. Drilling wastes include solids from brine water and drilling mud, while associated wastes are tank bottoms, contaminated soil and scale or sludges from radioactive materials.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS
The system boundary includes incoming fuel use, crude oil extraction, and process waste management. The following are excluded from the unit process boundary: miscellaneous materials and additives, capital equipment, facilities and infrastructure, space conditioning, and support personnel requirements.

DATA COLLECTION
Secondary data were collected from NETL, National Emissions Inventory, GREET 2017, EPA, and Cooney et al. 2017.

UNCERTAINTY ESTIMATION
No uncertainty analysis was carried out due to the lack of uncertainty data or probability distributions for key parameters, which are often only available as single point estimates from NETL.
processDocumentation.dataCollectionDescription: Primary data from GREET were collected from 2006-2013.

sources.name: Franklin Associates (2020). Cradle-to-Gate Life Cycle Analysis of Olefins

reviews.details: Internal review of data entry proofreading, mass balance verification and data documentation.

reviewers.name: Franklin Associates, A Division of ERG

processDocumentation.intendedApplication: The intended application for this process is for accounting purposes as described in Goal Situation C1 from the ILCD Handbook's Detailed Guidance. LCA studies with this intended application offer "purely descriptive documentation of the system under analysis (e.g., a product, sector or country), without being interested in any potential consequences on other parts of the economy.” The studies categorized under Goal Situation C1 do consider existing benefits outside the analyzed system such as recycling. A full inventory of environmental flows are included; thus this unit process can be used for a full range of LCIA impact categories. The target audience of this model includes LCA practitioners, industry, and the general public. For use as an average dataset accepted by the North American plastics/chemical industry. An inventory of environmental emission flows are included to the extent that the producers provided; thus this unit process can be used for a full range of LCIA impact categories. The original study results were analyzed using the TRACI LCIA factors.
processDocumentation.projectDescription: This project was funded by and submitted to the American Chemistry Council. These data are a background dataset used in the Cradle-to-Gate Life Cycle Analysis of Olefins report. Submitted to the American Chemistry Council (ACC). 2020.

dataGenerator.name: Franklin Associates, A Division of ERG

dataDocumentor.name: Franklin Associates, A Division of ERG

publication.name: Franklin Associates (2020). Cradle-to-Gate Life Cycle Analysis of Olefins
